body: Mental health occupies a unique place in the NHS workforce. Although some staff work in an acute setting, most work in the community as part of a team with other professionals, including psychiatrists, psychologists, mental health nurses, social workers and occupational therapists. The work is characterised, says Ian Hulatt, professional lead for mental health at the Royal College of Nursing, by a “strong multidisciplinary ethos”. There are a variety of specialisms on offer, Hulatt says. “They may work in early intervention teams with people having their first episode of psychosis, in outreach teams with clients that are difficult to engage with and perhaps need a lot more support, or they may work in a community drug and alcohol team.” Staff can also work in child and adolescent mental health services, with prisoners and, increasingly, with older people who have dementia. Perhaps more than other areas of the NHS, the mental health workforce suffers from staff shortages: 6% of consultant psychiatrist positions are unfilled and, in parts of London, 20% of mental health nursing posts are empty. Support staff (on Agenda for Change pay bands 1-4) make up 40% of the mental health workforce. There is currently no direct route for them to move into registered roles, but the sector skills council Skills for Health is helping to develop bridging programmes that will make it easier for them to access the training required to progress. Skills for Health senior consultant Hilary Wyles says that more support workers are needed: “The demographic of the support workforce is generally skewed towards the older end, and historically it’s been difficult to recruit young people into mental health services.” The organisation has successfully been working with some trusts, such as Humber NHS foundation trust, to create apprenticeships as a route into mental health support work. Mental health is also unusual in employing peer-support workers – former service users who can offer guidance to mental-health patients. Vicki Nash, head of policy and campaigns at Mind, says they are invaluable: “They’ve been through that experience and understand it in a way that [others] wouldn’t necessarily do if you hadn’t had that experience.” Not all trusts employ peer-support workers, however, and, of those who do, not all pay them. This may change, says Nash. The recent Five Year Forward View for Mental Health report by the independent Mental Health Taskforce, “makes it clear that paid peer support needs to be part of the workforce.” Perhaps more than any other area of the NHS, mental health work requires a range of approaches, treatments and perspectives. Hulatt says: “It’s not all about medicines.” Join the Healthcare Professionals Network to read more pieces like this. webTitle: Mental health and the NHS: a story of staff shortages and specialisms
